After the LAST CREDIT:
It is late. A car is speeding along.
Seated in the rear, Grant looks as if he has just been ar sleep and hustled into the car in a hurry. He is getting shirt, helped by a MAN beside him. There is a smudge of l his cheek.
Sorry we had to get you up at this hour, Mr. Grant.
(yawning) I thought I was on my vacation... What's it all about?
I can't tell you.
Where we going?
I can't tell you that either... Excuse me, Mr. Grant, but you've got a smudge on your cheek.
He takes out handkerchief, realizing Grant can't see it.
May I?
Go ahead.
As Grant finishes buttoning on his shirt, the Man rubs of lipstick. Then he throws the handkerchief out of the car.
What'd you do that for?
I'm married.
And she said it was indelible...
The car bearing Grant pulls up on an unpaved parking area loading trucks. Nothing stirs. The DRIVER shuts off the e lights.
The Driver and the Man in the rear get out. As Grant star
You're to stay inside, Mr. Grant. (answering look) And wait...
They close their respective doors, leaving Grant alone in looking out mystified into the darkness.
The two men move off together, until they reach what they know is a proscribed distance from the car. Then they sto it. For a moment nothing happens, then the ground seeming sink with the car.
Grant is startled to see the earth sliding up past the ca
It now becomes apparent that the car has been resting on really the top of an elevator shaft. The sides of the sha visible: it is seemingly bottomless.
Grant responds as the elevator finally comes to a halt.

The car is on the earthen platform. Two big doors open. A bearing the distinctive insignia of the <CMDF> appears, d M.P. wearing the same emblem. Grant gets out of the car, the M.P. into the scooter. He gets in, is driven away.

MALE and FEMALE OFFICERS, all in the uniform of the <CMDF about busily. As the M.P. and Grant drive across the foye the Female CMDFs appreciatively. Their uniforms emphasize points. The scooter reaches:
The OFFICER behind the desk looks up.
Your I.D. card, please.

Grant takes out a card with only an embossed number. The places it into an IDENTIFIER. As the scooter nears the Sentry Box, the M.P. on duty hit The steel doors slide open. The scooter goes through into
GENERAL ALAN CARTER is coming out of a door in a hurry. T bearing Grant pulls up beside him. Grant gets out. They s
Hello, Grant. Good to see you again.
The Pentagon, wasn't it, General? Only you weren't in that uniform...

They move to window overlooking the OPERATING ROOM, see t unconscious Benes being wheeled in for Surgery. His head The full shock of hair stands out against the white pillo is draped in the usual manner. A battery of SPECIALISTS a ATTENDANTS, MALE and FEMALE, are moving about under the g focused on the Operating Table.
(startled) Benes... What the devil happened?
The Other Side got to him.
How bad off is he?
Brain injury.
Before or after what he wanted to tell you?
Before he could breathe a word. He's the only scientist who knows the answer to what we're after. That's why we have to operate --
He turns away from the window, moves toward another door, following.
-- and why we need you.
<Me>?
Bewildered, he follows Carter through door into:
Carter moves to a panel of many switches and TV screens.
I can't even put a Band-Aid on my finger.
Here's the Surgeon.

He flicks a switch. On the TV screen appears the INTERIOR OFFICE. We see DUVAL, a brain surgeon in the middle forti the manner of one totally dedicated to his work. At the m testing a ruby laser, narrowing the beam down to pencil-l Assisting him is CORA PETERSON. In the middle twenties, h attractiveness is matched by her efficiency, which is con They work together smoothly, the result of long associati evident neither know they are being observed during:
Duval. Dr. Peter Duval. Top brain man in the country. Ever hear of him?
Sorry, but I'm rusty on surgeons. Who's the girl?
Cora Peterson, his Technical Assistant. You'll join Duval and the others --
What can I do? Except maybe pass out?
Carter flips on another switch. On the TV screen appears OF DR. MICHAELS' OFFICE. It is dominated by big blowups o Circulation System. Michaels is asaembling charts, as if pressure.
(on loudspeaker) Mike...
Michaels moves to a wall, presses a switch. His TV screen and Carter.
Yes, Alan.
Meet Grant. This is Dr. Michaels, Chief of the Medical Section.
Glad to have you with us, Mr. Grant.
Wish I knew why.
Tell him where he fits in, will you? I've got a few things to check out.
He moves to another panell is seen throwing on switches, fast series of scenes, all of which are indistinguishable shot. Michaels is seen bustling about, collecting charts
We need you for Security purposes, Mr. Grant.
At an operation?
They know they failed to kill Benes. Security thinks they'll try again, first chance they get. We're afraid of medical sabotage -- or surgical assassination.
Surgical assassination?! But that means you suspect --
(re-entering scene) [LINE OF DIALOGUE CUT OFF]
I don't agree. Just because he's often difficult --
Difficult? He's impossible!
That's no reason to suspect him of disloyalty.
But why take the chance, when there must be other doctors?
We have no choice. Duval's the most skillful brain surgeon in the country, and he's right here, at hand.
I wouldn't know if he's trying to save him or kill him.
I'll be standing by. <I'll> know.
(to Grant) And no matter what happens, you're to take orders <only> from Dr. Michaels, understand?
Right, sir.
Come along, they'll be operating shortly. (hand on switch) See you later, Mike.
Michaels waves. Carter switches off the monitor. He moves Grant follows.
As they emerge:
His technician okay? In addition to the Looks Department?
No question of her loyalty.
As Carter leads Grant to the scooter and they take their looks at the big <CMDF> insignia on the floor.
I don't mean to be inquisitive. But this <CMDF> -- for all I know it could stand for <Consolidated Mobilization of Female Delinquents>?
(matter-of-fact) <Combined Miniature Deterrent Forces>.
(blankly) Say that again?
Carter starts the scooter and they drive through the big out of the Medical Foyer.
We can reduce anything down to any size we want. People -- ships -- tanks --planes...
General, I've heard some wild ones. But this takes it.
We can shrink an Army -- with all its equipment -- and put it in a bottle cap. That's why we call it <Combined Miniature Deterrent Forces>.
(with silent whistle) If the Other Side ever gets hold of a thing like that...

They have... (answering look) But we've both got the same problem -- lack or control. We can only keep things Miniaturized for exactly sixty minutes. Arter that, everything starts growing back to its original size.
They arrive at the root of the escalator, leave the scoot the moving stairway.
As they ride up:
I assume Benes knows how to control it.
That's right. He wanted us to have the secret, and not them. Which is why they tried to kill him.
They're bound to try again. No wonder they want me to stand by during the operation.
And take a little trip with them...
(bewildered) Trip? Where to?

(matter-of-fact) Well, the only way to reach that clot is from inside the Brain. So we've decided to put a Surgical Team and a Crew into a submarine -- reduce it way down in size, and inject it into an Artery --
(jolted) You mean <I'm> going along?
As part of the Crew.
Wait a minute! They can't shrink <me>!
(assuringly) Grant, our Miniaturizer can shrink anything.
But I don't want to be Miniaturized -- !
It's only for an hour --
Not even for a minute! General Carter, sir, I'd like you to reconsider your choice. I'm just not the right man for a mission of this kind.
He starts walking against the direction of the escalator, remaining in the same place.
(taking his arm) Come on, Grant. You're going to a Briefing.
They have reached the top of the escalator. Nearby is a d
Carter opens the door, waves him in.

Grant and Carter enter in the middle of what is evidently argument between COLONEL DONALD REID and Duval. Reid is i of the <CMDF>, with a cadaceus which indicates he is the Division. Also present is CAPTAIN BILL OWENS, in Naval un Michaels. Cora stands beside Duval, rather abashed, since cause of the vociferous disagreement.
(irascibly) Miss Peterson volunteered to come along!
So did every male Technician in the Unit. A woman has no place on a mission of this kind.
(brooking no rebuttal) I insist on taking my Technician.
You'll take whoever <I> assign!
(angrily) Don't tell me whom I'm to work with! Not on this operation or any other! I'll do what <I> think is best, without any interference from anyone!
Before Reid can reply:
(diplomatically) Dr. Duval has relied on Miss Peterson for years. And since she wants to come along, I'm sure it's for the best, Dr. Reid.
(making best of defeat) I don't agree with you -- but since you're in charge, you can do as you please. But I want to go on record as being against it.
Grant -- Colonel Reid, Operation Commander. (they nod; of Michaels) You've met our Medical Chief.
Grant and Michaels shake hands, in effect their first mee vis.
This is Dr. Duval, our Head Surgeon.
Oh yes, I've heard of you, Doctor.
With the attitude of the completely dedicated professiona throws him a cursory glance, nods, sits down, quickly ope folder containing the latest lab reports on Benes, which during:
Miss Peterson, his Technical Assistant.
(the charmer) How are you, Miss Peterson?
She responds with an impersonal nod, sits down beside Duv up her sheaf of lab reports, handing him the pertinent on
This is Captain Bill Owens, designer of an experimental submarine for the Navy's 'Oceanographic Research and Development Program.'
As they shake hands:
Out of your element, aren't you, Captain?
Sort of.
That makes two of us.

Grant's uniquely qualified for this mission. He's a Communications Expert and was a Frogman during the War. Besides, he brought Benes into this country, and the fewer people who know about him, the better. At any rate, you'll find Grant invaluable, should anything go wrong once you're under way. (to Reid) Okay, Don.
Here's the overall Target Area...

Reid presses a switch. A large anatomical map of a Brain central screen. The ganglia and dendrites form a network, intersecting roads, in a detailed war map. The clot is a obstruction in the center. Grid lines cross the map verti horizontally as points of reference. The entire projectio three-dimensional effect, since it is drawn in perspectiv
Benes' brain...near as we can map it stereotaxically...
He switches on a flashlight arrow, points to the clot.
The clot's right here...

He switches off the arrow and quickly flashes it on again on the edges of the map. The arrow now probes and with dr base, center and top of the brain, like the animated tech showing an attack which is repulsed at the perimeter.
Impossible to get at -- (arrow makes vertical penetration to give impression of wide cut) -- without damage to the intervening tissue...which would prove fatal to Benes.

He presses another switch. A startling OVERLAY OF THE BLO THE HEAD AND NECK appears over the anatomical drawing of encasing it. The red-colored arteries and blue-colored ve an intricate maze, that finding one's way through it seem impossible.
The only way to reach it is via the Arterial System.
Grant looks at Cora. She is busy making notes from the pr Owens is showing no undue reaction, apparently having bee
Phase One calls for Miniaturizing a submarine, with Crew and Surgical Team, and injecting it into the Carotid Artery.
He points with the arrow to the exact spot.
How small would that be?
About the size of a microbe.
Colonel, I'm sure that's quite a comfortable size, but --
Reduced proportionately, you won't find it too strange --
All in a day's work, sure. But I was thinking of the speed of the Circulatory System.
About forty miles an hour.
Well, it seems to me if you reduce a ship to microscopic size -- and the stream remains constant -- we'd take quite a beating.
(very worried) I hope you've taken that into account --
We have.

You won't be going anywhere near that fast. We're putting Benes in deep Hypothermia -- that is, freezing him low as compatible with human life. It'll slow down his heartbeat, Circulation, and all other physical processes.
Owens begins polishing his glasses, indicating his inner
Even so, because of our size -- I mean lack of it -- we'll still be cruising mighty fast. We'll be smashed to bits if there's any turbulence --

(pointing with flashing arrow) The only danger of turbulence is in the Heart -- and we're not going through it. (flashing arrow) Once in the Carotid Artery, we'll remain in the Arterial System... until we reach the point of damage -- (flashes around clot) -- where Dr. Duval will attempt to dissolve the clot with a laser beam. After the operation, we'll return by way of the Venous System -- (coursing down with arrow) -- until we reach the base of the neck -- (arrow stops) -- where we'll be removed right here -- with a hypodermic.
How will you know where the sub is, at any particular moment?

Dr. Michaels -- our Circulatory Specialist -- will serve as your Navigator. He'll know just where you are. And you can communicate directly with us, by wireless. Besides, the sub is nuclear-powered, and we'll be tracking it just as we would any radio-active tracer.

There'll be a team of Surgeons standing by. We're prepared to remove you immediately, should anything go wrong. In any event, you must be out within sixty minutes. After that, you'll be in danger of attack.
Attack? Who -- or should I say what from?
Benes' natural defenses. White Corpuscles -- Antibodies. Once you begin to grow -- and become a menace to the body -- you'll trigger them off...
With all the unknown factors in the body, I still say risking five lives for one is something we should reconsider --
We understand your concern, but we've made our decision, Doctor. Any questions? Anybody?
Just one, General...
Yes?
Where can I get a cab back to town?
No one responds to the attempted levity. Carter rises.
(to all) Proceed to the Sterilization Section.
Carter and Reid move out of the room through the door. Th out through another.

How much can a man give to his country?
The door swings automatically shut behind him.

(over TV) Holding steady at thirty-two per minute.
(to another Technician) Respiration.

The Technician flips on another switch. On a TV screen ap INTERIOR OF THE RESPIRATION POST. Here everything relates lungs. In addition to cut-away sections where each small the proportions of a detailed war map, there are banks of X-rays, lit up in panels, plus immense calibrated charts INHALATION and EXHALATION, on which the rate is being ele recorded.
How's he doing, Jack?

(over TV) Respiration is now six per minute... I wouldn't take him down any further.

Hypothermia...

On a TV screen appears the INTERIOR OF THE HYPOTHERMIA PO festooned with dials recording bodily temperature, before TECHNICIANS sit watching and making minute adjustments. T HYPOTHERMIA SPECIALIST moves along, keeping a sharp eye o zones labeled: CIRCULATORY, RESPIRATORY, CARDIAC, RENAL,
Any problems, Dr. Sawyer?
(over TV) No sir. We're holding him at twenty- eight degrees Centigrade.
Carter enters, moves to the Control Section to join Reid.
Where do we stand?
Medical's ready.
The Communications Aide with headphones moves up to them.
They're in the Sterilization Corridor --

Bathed in eerie ultra-violet light. The five are passing corridor, in single file. All are dressed in khaki unifor moves ahead of Cora. As they reach a vestibule at the end swings open automatically. Grant starts to help Cora over threshold.
Don't touch me. I'm sterile.
Grant grins. They move into:

A huge parquet area, composed of white octagonal modules. center is the Zero Module, in red. Standing over it is a craft. The angle and the distance renders its details ind WHITE-CLAD TECHNICIANS wearing rubber gloves are seen wor it. As the five come into the room:

He puts the Seed Cage on the cradle and lowers it back be floor, by reversing the crank. During the above:

They can't reduce nuclear fuel. But once the Reactor's Miniaturized -- along with the submarine -- a microscopic particle should emit enough energy to activate it.

It should work -- theoretically. If it doesn't, the mission's off. The craft's nuclear-powered. Except for your wireless.
The lid of the trap door is now level with the floor. Owe the crank, and taking the lead box from Grant, he puts bo the tool box during:

Designed for Piscatorial Research -- the Spawning Habits of Deep Sea Fish.
Remind me to ask you about the love life of an octupus.
He moves to the wireless, sees Cora smile as she goes thr door. Grant begins tapping out a message.
A WIRELESS TECHNICIAN is writing down the message heard c tears it off his pad, hands it to the Communications Aide it to Carter.
Test message from the Proteus, sir. (reading) 'Miss Peterson has smiled.'

Confirm receiving.

Grant is at the wireless, logging the incoming message. I meantime, Owens finishes battening down the entrance hatc studying medical reports, Michaels is spreading out the f Navigation Charts, a very detailed map of the Vascular Sy Neck and Head. On the Repeater.

Once the power's on, we'll be in direct touch. Come, I'll show you.

An ultra-sophisticated set of controls, consisting of a p panel and an airplane-like steering wheel. The plastic af degree view of the Miniaturization Room. There is room fo person. Owens remains on the ladder, so that only his hea the Bubble. Owens points to the identical Repeater on the

(of controls; ironically) Looks simple to operate.
He sits down in the single seat.

(from Bubble; with pride) It actually is, although the controls are highly sophisticated. There's a button for everything --
Grant enters:

Originally designed for marine research, it still shows s pre-adaptation structure: there is a series of glass-fron compartments, now labeled ANTIBIOTICS, ANTI-COAGULANTS, C MED OXY, etc. A wide counter runs the length of the compa side, suitable for working on specimens. A Ruby Laser sit counter at the end, its plastic cover removed and to the other is a piece of metal on a metal base. As Grant enter Cora working with a set of very small tools, making minut on the laser.
Bet you're pretty handy around the house... Can you cook?
(indicating oxy containers) We're pushing oxygen today.
I'll take some Laughing Gas, ma'am.
(surprised) You sound as if you're not looking forward to it.
Well, it's not exactly a pleasure cruise.
I think it's the most exciting -- (with awe) We're going to see things no one ever saw before. The actual physical process of Life itself -- not something under a microscope... Just think of it --
That's the trouble. I am. Being shrunk...
You may learn to like it.
She has finished adjusting the laser. She now lifts Grant from the metal disc.
Excuse me...
She presses a button on the laser. With startling suddenn pencil of light shoots out, cutting a hole through the me instantaneously. Had Grant's hand remained, the beam woul right through it.
For a nice young lady, you play with the damndest toys, Miss Peterson...
She adjusts the intensity and thickness of the laser beam one cutting different size holes through the metal during
(with smile) That'll teach you where to keep your hand.
Now I know...
As she drills metal through again:
That could be quite a lethal weapon... It could kill, not cure.
Not in the hands of a great surgeon like Dr. Duval. The beam of this laser can be regulated to one millionth of a millimeter.
I understand you've been Dr. Duval's Assistant for quite some time... He must've snatched you out of the cradle.
I've been with him since I got out of school. He brought me into the CMDF, over five years ago.
A long time, with one man.
Not working for someone like Dr. Duval --

(with difficulty) Doctor...

I -- I want to say...

What is it? (anxiously) Anything wrong?
(the moment gone) I just wanted to thank you for taking me along.
